subject: Gardening
title: Can Plants Learn?
description: A quick, practical guide to Can Plants Learn?.

hook.text: Mimosa pudica stops folding when repeatedly dropped. It retains this learned response for up to 28 days.

buildup.text: Monica Gagliano's 2014 experiment showed Mimosa habituating to a harmless stimulusâ€”classic learning behavior.

discovery.text: The plants distinguished between being dropped and being shaken. They still folded for novel threats.

twist.text: Critics argued this was just cellular fatigue, not learning. But the 28-day retention period disproved that.

climax.text: If learning requires memory, discrimination, and retentionâ€”Mimosa checks all three boxes, without a single neuron.

punchline.text: A plant with no brain can form 28-day memories.

quiz.question: What evidence suggests Mimosa pudica can learn, not just fatigue?
options: It responded differently to different threats and retained the memory for 28 days
It grew new leaves faster after repeated stimulation
Its chemical composition changed permanently after the experiment
